issue.title: [ENH] deprecation warning for start_with_window in ExpandingWindowSplitter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Realizes #2678 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Helps to make the code less confusing for the users and lets them set values in a more intuitive and direct manner. This PR lays the groundwork for the planned deprecation of `start_with_window` in `ExpandingWindowSplitter`. The tasks this PR seeks to realize are:

1. provide users the ability to set initial_window to 0 _and have it actually be set to 0_
2. displays a new `FutureWarning` message prompted when the user sets the default for `start_with_window` to be `False` instead of the default value which is `True`. This way we can warn our users about the coming change and allow them time to make the necessary changes.

issue.title: [ENH] Allow Window Splitter objects to accept `n_splits` parameter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When benchmarking datasets with many series, we may want to compute the average score for all backtesting windows. If different series have different lengths, they will likely have different counts of backtest windows, and the overall mean score will suffer from sampling bias.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Be able to pass `n_splits` to `ExpandingWindowSplitter` and `SlidingWindowSplitter`, so that regardless of input series length we will know how many windows will be computed for each series. The function would require `series`, `fh`, `n_splits`, and could optionally still accept `initial_window`. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
In the backtesting loop, the user could compute the window params based on the series length for each series themselves.

This work is inspired by @topher-lo's work on parellelizing the `evaluate` function, and he has already shared some code for computing window sizes and season periods based on the series `freq` attribute.

body:
@fkiraly I'm taking this on and already have code that may be working as planned. My questions before I submit the PR:
1. Do we also want to remove `start_with_window` for `SlidingWindowSplitter`? The design choice of allowing `initial_window=0` replace `start_with_window` would seem the same to me but slightly different implementations.
2. If we do want to remove this for `SlidingWindowSplitter`, what is the expected behavior for the params `initial_window=0`, `window_length=4`, and `step_size=2`? The first training window would be `[]`. Would the second follow the logic of `step_size` and contain `[0,1]` (where the end of the training set took a step of 2 past the last one), or would it always obey `window_length` and have a next two training sets of `[0,1,2,3]` and `[2,3,4,5]` (where the end of the training window went up by more than `step_size`)?

After the initial empty window we can only respect one of `step_size` or `window_length` in this case.

> 1. Do we also want to remove `start_with_window` for `SlidingWindowSplitter`? The design choice of allowing `initial_window=0` replace `start_with_window` would seem the same to me but slightly different implementations.

Hm, not sure what that would be.
What is the current behaviour if `start_with_window` is `False`?

Either case, I would say this should be a separate PR/issue.

> What is the current behaviour if start_with_window is False?

The current implementation respects the `step_length`, because the internal logic increments the end of the window by that length to create each new window.
```
splitter = SlidingWindowSplitter(fh=[1,2], step_length=2, window_length=4, start_with_window=False)
list(splitter.split(ts))

out >
[(array([], dtype=int64), array([0, 1])),
 (array([0, 1]), array([2, 3])),
 (array([0, 1, 2, 3]), array([4, 5])),
 (array([2, 3, 4, 5]), array([6, 7])),
 (array([4, 5, 6, 7]), array([8, 9]))]
```

> Either case, I would say this should be a separate PR/issue.

The changes I've made for this issue in `BaseWindowSplitter` would change the design for both subclasses (to allowing `initial_window=0`) and would keep the behavior described above the same for the `SlidingWindowSplitter` (respecting `step_length`. In this case could this just be one PR?

Also @fkiraly could you point me to an example of correct usage for `deprecated` when it is just for a single parameter or piece of functionality and not a whole method, function, or class like in the above document? That could also be a potential opportunity for improvement in [the doc](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/developer_guide/deprecation.html) for next time somebody has the same question.

issue.title: [ENH] Fix for initial_window=0 and depreciating "start_with_window" in ExpandingWindowSplittter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #2678 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
`ExpandingWindowSplitter` now has consistent behavior when `start_with_window=False` or `initial_window=0`. In the case of the former, a warning is raised that `start_with_window` will be depreciated in version 0.15.0. 

Due to these changes, `SlidingWindowSplittter` can now accept `initial_window=0`, and no other behavior was changed.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

I imported `warn` but no real deps.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #2678 - follows PR 3685.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
`ExpandingWindowSplitter` now has consistent behavior when `start_with_window=False` or `initial_window=0`. In the case of the former, a warning is raised that `start_with_window` will be depreciated in version 0.15.0.

Also includes a test case for when `initial_window=0` with `ExpandingWindowSplitter`. 

Unlike the last PR, the scope does not affect behavior of `SlidingWindowSplitter`. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

I imported `warn` but no real deps.

issue.title: [BUG] fix `start_with_window` deprecation in `ExpandingWindowSplitter`

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
It would appear the deprecation of `start_with_window` in `ExpandingWindowSplitter` according to https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2678 was carried out incompletely - simply carrying out the deprecation action results in error, due to the parameter still being there in super calls and base constructor.

This PR introduces a quick fix which translates the parameter in `ExpandingWindowSplitter`, to the desired deprecation end state, but without full removal of the parameter in the base interface.

The original deprecation in #2678 still needs to be carried out fully.

body:
I think this was not carried out correctly, I unfortunately did not spot that in the PR review (did I review that?)

It looks like the parameter got removed, but no further logic got introduced, e.g., dealing with the parameter in the base class or super call.

See https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3953 for more details on what is missing.

FYI @chillerobscuro - don't worry, this was a bit subtle and not easy to spot.

Learning moment: the code should have been tested (by author and PR reviewer!) in its state after the suggested deprecation actions.

Thanks for your contribution!
